title: 103_s1127
content: Title XI of the Higher Education Act of 1965 is amended to include a new part called "Rural Community Service" with the purpose of providing findings and establishing a program for rural community service. The Congress finds that rural centers are facing pressing problems in various areas, and there are people in rural institutions with underutilized skills that can help address these issues. The purpose of this part is to provide incentives to rural academic institutions to enable them to contribute towards solving rural problems. The purpose of this part is to provide incentives to rural academic institutions to work with organizations and address pressing problems in their communities. The Secretary is authorized to carry out a program providing assistance to eligible institutions for authorized activities in accordance with this part. Applications for rural community service grants are also outlined. Each eligible institution seeking a grant must submit an application to the Secretary, detailing the activities and services for which assistance is needed. The institution must also agree to form a consortium with entities such as a community college, rural local educational agency, local government, business, or nonprofit institution to implement the program. The Secretary has the authority to waive the consortium requirement. The Secretary may waive consortium requirements for applicants demonstrating an integrated plan. Priority is given to joint projects with other programs. Selection procedures will be outlined in regulations published in the Federal Register. "Authorized activities under SEC. 1174 include waivers for consortium requirements and priority for joint projects with other programs." Grant funds under this part support planning, research, training, and services to assist rural communities with workforce preparation, poverty alleviation, healthcare, education, elderly and disability issues, family and children problems, crime prevention, housing, infrastructure, economic development, farming, and environmental concerns. The curr_chunk focuses on addressing various issues in rural areas, including housing, infrastructure, economic development, farming, environmental concerns, accessibility to institutions for individuals with disabilities, and attitudinal barriers. These are identified as high priority areas by participants in the consortium described in the previous paragraph. The Secretary will appoint a peer review panel to evaluate applications for funding under this part. The panel will be geographically diverse and include experts from various sectors. Funds will be disbursed according to the panel's recommendations. "Grants under this part may be awarded on a multiyear basis, with a maximum of 5 years per institution. The Secretary will ensure equitable geographic distribution of grants and require a matching contribution from applicants and local governments. Rural grant institutions will be designated under this section." The Secretary will designate eligible institutions as 'Rural Grant Institutions' and establish a national network for sharing project results. The term 'rural area' refers to areas outside urbanized areas with populations of 75,000 or more. An 'eligible institution' is an institution of higher education located in a rural area that serves students from rural or contiguous areas and promotes postsecondary educational opportunities for residents in those areas. An eligible institution of higher education in a rural area serves students from rural or contiguous areas, making postsecondary educational opportunities more accessible. The institution must have the capacity to provide resources responsive to the needs of the rural areas, offer professional programs, and demonstrate a sustained sense of responsibility to the community. Authorization of appropriations is granted for necessary funds each fiscal year to implement the provisions of this part. If the amount appropriated is less than 50 percent of the funds for part A, the Secretary will allocate the difference from part A funds.
